subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... The use is whatever the community decides the use is, at the end of the day.  Read doesn t express himself very well in the manual, but what he *means* is
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> > Please note the word "originally". QS was originally designed around
> > RP, and RP uses these three sounds in those three words.
>
> That is a very weak argument and also avoids the topic. I am trying to
> get clarity on the use of these vowels amongst others.

The use is whatever the community decides the use is, at the end of
the day. Read doesn't express himself very well in the manual,
but what he *means* is plain as a pikestaff if you know anything
about RP. If you don't, then I suppose it isn't.

> > > How can you possibly say there is no doubt when other users have
> > > expressed confusion and when you know that no everyone speaks British
> > > English?
> >
> > There is no doubt about the above historical and phonological facts.
>
> Which most of us are not aware of. So again, there is great doubt.

*shrug*

If by "doubt" you mean "ignorance", then I'll agree.

> So I'm not supposed to be able to follow your posts when you make
> contradictions!

*plonk*

> By the way, could you please tell me how much you use
> QS? I asked you that in another post and I guess you never got around to
> answering it.

True. I've used JQS just a little bit, trying to get familiar with how
to write it and how it differs from Shavian. I'm certainly not an
extensive user of it, though if I felt the need to use shorthand I might
become one.

--
Do what you will, John Cowan
this Life's a Fiction cowan@...
And is made up of http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
Contradiction. --William Blake
